title: Swampy Daniel Hooper among Extinction Rebellion protests in Wales
text:
Eco warrior 'Swampy', real name Daniel Hooper, is back to his old tricks and was fined over a protest this week

Nineties eco warrior 'Swampy' was today fined for blockading one of Britain's largest oil refineries in an Extinction Rebellion protest.

Daniel Hooper, who found fame after his tree and tunneling protests against new roads, handcuffed himself to a concrete block at the entrance to the giant Valero plant in Pembroke, West Wales.

He was fined £40 after admitting willful obstruction of the highway and telling magistrates in Haverfordwest: 'I was doing it to prevent a greater crime, the eco crime of profit at the cost of the planet. I am pleading guilty, I can't really afford to keep coming to court.'

Swampy, now 42, lives in the picturesque Welsh village of Talley in Carmarthenshire, known for its community of environmentalists who live in teepees.

He was one of 10 Extinction Rebellion protestors who blocked three entrances to the oil refinery last month.

The 42-year-old represented himself in court and was ordered to pay £85 in court costs and a £32 surcharge.

Hooper found fame with the nickname Swampy in 1996 after becoming the face of the Newbury bypass protests by living in tunnels under the roadworks.

He and others also climbed trees due to be felled for the construction of the new road.

Hooper, known as 'Swampy', rose to fame in the 1990s when he protested against the Newbury bypass. He is pictured in one of his tunnels in 1997

After getting involved in a similar protest against the extension of the A30 in Devon he appeared on the BBC's Have I Got News For You.

He was reported to have been involved in the 2007 climate change protests at London Heathrow Airport but has kept a relatively low profile ever since.

As of 2013 he was still registered as living in the New Age commune in Wales with his family.

Extinction Rebellion protests are going on in towns and cities around the world this week.

So far 319 activists have been arrested for various offences in London, according to the Metropolitan Police.
